Alexander Marshack, The Roots of Civilization (Wakefield: Moyer Bell, 1992) is a pioneering work on the earliest records of astronomical interest among Old Stone Age populations. And a reliable survey of the entire field across the world is Robert J
The journal Archaeoastronomy is a valuable, if specialized, source

note: Anthony Aveni, World Archaeoastronomy (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1989) covers the subject extensively. On Stonehenge, see Jean-Pierre Mohen, The World Megaliths (New York: Facts on File, 1990
also remains a valuable study. And Jo Anne Van Tilburg, Easter Island: Archaeology, Ecology, and Culture
provides an authoritative introduction.
title: The Neolithic era is mainly the province of the archaeologist. An authoritative overview is Colin Renfrew and Paul Bahn, Archaeology: Theories, Methods, and Practice
Astronomy in the preliterate Neolithic is accessible only through its architectural monuments
Stonehenge Complete

container-title: Monumental building in the centralized state was, in complexity, an order of magnitude beyond Neolithic structures: on the Egyptian case, see J.-P. Lepre, The Egyptian Pyramids: A Comprehensive, Illustrated Reference
Hawass, The Pyramids of Ancient Egypt
note: and, for an attempt by a physicist to explain the purposes of the ancient pharaohs in undertaking their great building projects, Kurt Mendelssohn, Riddle of the Pyramids (New York: Thames and Hudson, 1986).
publisher: Institute for the Study of Human Issues
title: CHAPTER 3. Pharaohs and Engineers The advent of civilization saw the origin of the centralized state, large cities, and higher learning. It was the beginning of the “historical” era—the first period to allow the historian to examine documents produced by human civilizations. An informative survey of early civilizations across the world is C
Ancient Civilizations: The Near East and Mesoamerica (Prospect Heights

is a learned and provocative, albeit idiosyncratic, approach to the subject

title: a masterpiece of scientific biography, is the essential starting point; see also its abridgement, The Life of Isaac Newton

publisher: New York Public Library/Oxford University Press
title: also provide standard accounts
is a similarly important introductory source. Mordechai Feingold, The Newtonian Moment: Isaac Newton and the Making of Modern Culture

title: inventively traces Newton’s changing reputation over time

container-title: Darwin on Evolution

note: has become the standard modern study.
title: Browne’s multivolume Charles Darwin: A Biography

container-title: The Darwinian Heritage

is a major collection of essays on the subject. The principle of natural selection receives a spirited presentation in Richard Dawkins, The Blind Watchmaker: Why the Evidence of Evolution Reveals a Universe Without Design
note: similar but more philosophical is Daniel C. Dennet’s Darwin’s Dangerous Idea
title: Bowler’s work, especially his Charles Darwin: The Man and His Influence
and Evolution: The History of an Idea

provides a solid historical overview to Darwin and the development of evolutionary theory as well as an entrée into the prodigious Darwin scholarship. The reader who requires assistance with the biological principles and their development in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries will find it in
Blueprints: Solving the Mystery of Evolution

container-title: Carl N. Degler, In Search of Human Nature: The Decline and Revival of Darwinism in American Social Thought
presents a thorough narrative of Darwinian controversies in the social sciences. And Edward O. Wilson, On Human Nature
note: is a popular discussion of sociobiology, one of the controversial results of evolutionary theory.
title: Jonathan Weiner, The Beak of the Finch: A Story of Evolution in Our Time
is a gracefully written account of evolution in action
